text: Look up a Youtuber named TokyoBrando I believe (hope his channel is still around) he uploaded the complete soundtracks in 3-4 hour videos of each of the classic SH games with unused tracks as well. If you've got time to kill and want some creepy atmosphere. Or just look up "Silent Hill 100% soundtrack" in the search bar.

text: This game might be my favorite or second-fave in the series. While it may not be best overall, there's a lot to it that is excellent and unnerving in a different way from its predecessors. I really should play through it again soon.

author: Haunting Pixels

text: Yamaoka went with quite a different style with this soundtrack compared to the previous games, which really isn't too surprising since the game itself also took a step away from the series' roots. I remember being disappointed by this game when I first beat it, but it's one of those games that you end up looking back more fondly, especially since it was the last game from Team Silent. The Room was definitely a well made and scary place (floating head outside the appartment anyone?). This dark atmospheric theme is surprisingly addicting, I often hit the replay button after a first listen. Well done, Yamaoka.
author: SupraDarky

text: The Room was certainly the weakest of Team Silent's games (at least, imo), but when comparing it to the likes of Homecoming and Downpour, it's leagues better.
author: Dalton McBleh

text: @Dalton McBleh I do give Homecoming some credit though. It did feel like a cinematic experience and it was Double Helix's very first game.
author: ArcRiseGen

text: @Sammy102093 Eh, to each his own. While I do like Double Helix (Strider and KI are great), I still think they fucked up majorly on Homecoming.
author: Dalton McBleh

text: What I love of SH4 is its mechanic of having a safe place in the first half and turning it into a possible death trap in the second half. Also the whole weird ambience and crazy stuff that can be seen happening in the background and the tons of extra artwork and music made it feel like there was more to it. For SH4 there are 3 official music albums as far as I know with some tracks that are present and others that are absent from the game. There are also some unofficial compilations made from the game files that have also music that apparently is absent from the game. Actually I think that the entire music from SH4, including absent tracks totals 4 hours.  Of course according to TP, Yamaoka composed part of the game music before taking a look at the actual game, hence the great amount of music.
author: Cenobyte321

text:
@Dalton McBleh
and every other game they've made. Its a pretty short list and the two you've named are the only good games on it.
author: Matt Guerrette

text: @SupraDarky Actually, SH4 is a case if what I call "Mario 2 Syndrome"; being its own title, at first, before being shoehorned into a popular franchise. So it stands to reason it might feel like a departure from the series norm.(Star Fox Adventures is another example I can think of off the top of my head)
author: EvilMariobot

text: @EvilMariobot Except for the fact that there is NO evidence supporting the idea that SH 4 was intended to be an original ip in development.  It's one of the most popular myths on the internet.
author: remotefreak147

text: Double Helix WAS forced to work on movie tie-in games by Activision though. The games they wanted to work on came out well.
